bibl.title: Letter from Myron [s.n.] to Laura Armistead Carter, May 4, 1931

div1.p: Cousin Myron writes that she is using Laura Carter's notes for a biographical sketch of Henry Carter.

div1.head: Letter from Myron [s.n.]to Laura Armistead Carter, May 4, 1931
div1.p:
Thank you for your promptness
and your trust. I have kept these
papers, not thinking you wanted
them so soon, because I have
been trying to collect as much
information from all available
sources as possible. In an essay
of 1500 words on ten people you
see very plainly that what I have
to say will have to be well digested
if it is to be effective. I am disap-
pointed that I have not been able
to learn from anywhere just what
part Uncle Henry had to do with
cleaning up Panama. He established
the Quarantine but I was under
the impression that his guidance
was a telling factor in the
splendid results. I am not clear
in my own mind as the full
C1
B20
part he has taken in discoveries
pertaining to Malaria and its con-
trol. I know he did a vast amount
of work of real importance.

It has been a real pleasure to
read these sketches and to get
a more intimate and intelligent
idea of the wonderfully important
work Uncle Henry did. I hope
some day to read the history he
wrote. In connection with that
work I recall so vividly his saying
that he was trying to do this part
of the history he was writing so
thoroughly and accurately that
it would never have to be done
again.

When the work lets up come to see
us. Bessie joins me with love to you
Thank you again.
div1.closer:
Affectionately Myron. (I am using the grand
envelope you sent).
